author: sky.cactus
content: I'm suspicious of the $21B in locked value number.  Many projects double, triple, quadruple, 10x *real* locked value numbers.

author: trent_vanepps
content: DeFiPulse has demonstrated they don't double count, but I am not deep into their methodology

author: sky.cactus
content: e.g., $1M ETH locked, and then users get a token representing their holdings (which is valued at $1M), and then they "stake" that token so the platform now claims to have $2M locked.

author: trent_vanepps
content: does the dollar value change the outcome of the polling? no

author: sky.cactus
content: Well, I wouldn't even mention that line personally.  ðŸ™‚

author: sky.cactus
content: I think it is a fairly silly measure myself.

author: sky.cactus
content: For example, Augur has fairly low TVL (relatively), but I think it is a far more meaningful project on Ethereum then yet-another-leverage-tool.

author: trent_vanepps
content: so you're discounting LP tokens as valuable collateral, which is what it is. i don't know if I can argue you out of that position

author: sky.cactus
content: FWIW: I generally like your application list.  You have things on there that have 0 locked value like Arbitrum and Optimism, which are both very important ecosystem applications.  You also have Etherscan, Gitcoin, GridPlus, etc. My complaint is *only* about the TVL line.  ðŸ˜„

author: sky.cactus
content: I'm not saying that LP tokens aren't valuable, only that they result in double counting (as in my example above).

author: trent_vanepps
content: i actually think it's a relevant signal, as these are projects with significant value attached to them - the results would mean less if the projects featured only had 10mm in value

author: trent_vanepps
content: point is that these projects have a lot on the line

author: trent_vanepps
content: i actually think there is 10s of millions on Optimism now

author: sky.cactus
content: They aren't even on mainnet yet are they?

author: trent_vanepps
content: synthetix is running a pilot program there

author: sky.cactus
content: I think this is where we disagree.  I care more about the long term health and progress of the ecosystem, which means I care more about projects that are providing (subjective) useful value toward that.  Layer 2 solutions, blockchain explorers, infrastructure providers, hardware wallets are things whose opinions I value far more than the latest fork of some popular project.

author: sky.cactus
content: And I actively *discount* the value of projects who literally steal code from other projects and then re-launch with a ponzi scheme on top (looking at you SushiSwap).

author: sky.cactus
content: Projects who have contributed significant innovation I would put next, even if they don't have a ton of TVL.  Augur, Maker, Uniswap heavily fall into this list for me even though I don't fully agree with all of their choices.

author: sky.cactus
content: After that are the projects that have iterated in useful ways on these concepts, like Curve, Balancer, Airswap, 1inch.

author: sky.cactus
content: Basically, TVL just never plays a role in my *personal* calculus for which projects I care about supporting.

author: trent_vanepps
content: what other infrastructure providers would you have pursued? there are a few we have in mind but didn't reach out to yet

author: trent_vanepps
content: why would hardware wallets matter?

author: sky.cactus
content: QuikNode, Alchemy.

author: sky.cactus
content: DuneAnalytics.

author: trent_vanepps
content: the point was to start with projects that will be most impacted by on-chain user activity

author: trent_vanepps
content: this means onchain apps with value running through them.

author: sky.cactus
content: Hardware wallets are a very useful/powerful tool for people to secure their assets on Ethereum.  They also have a very different set of problems/difficulties/constraints from other participants in the ecosystem.  If they have a problem with EIP-1559, I would *definitely* like to hear it.

author: trent_vanepps
content: perhaps next time I can start with a ranking by active addresses - though I suspect it will be the same

author: sky.cactus
content: Another metric I care fairly little about.  ðŸ™‚

author: trent_vanepps
content: i think it's clear we have different philosophies on this! but in reality this is only the initial set. any project can make a PR to add their position, and I will continue adding to my list to hit next

author: trent_vanepps
content: suggestions welcome ðŸ™‚

author: sky.cactus
content: Sablier is a great example of a dapp that I think provides significant value and creates a new mechanism for paying employees/contractors that should definitely be part of the future of finance, but I don't know if it has a huge number of users or TVL.

author: sky.cactus
content: Yeah, and to reiterate, I like most your list and thank you very much for putting this together!  I literally was **only** complaining about that one sentence in the middle.  ðŸ˜„

author: trent_vanepps
content: appreciate it!

author: timbeiko
content: Write-up on the large state performance test we did a few weeks ago, and the ensuing debugging we did on Besu: https://hackmd.io/@timbeiko/1559-perf-test

author: foobar0x
content:
Could someone point me to estimates of the steady-state `BASEFEE` and `TIP` after EIP-1559? For example, suppose that today's steady-state gas cost is a median of 150 gwei and an average of 200 gwei. Which of the following corresponds to this?

- basefee 140, tip 10
- basefee 190, tip 10
- basefee 10, tip 140
- basefee 10, tip 190

Sorry if this has been discussed before, wasn't able to find it!

author: sky.cactus
content: Under normal conditions, the expectation would be that base_fee would be 149 or 199 and inclusion fee (tip) would be 1.

author: sky.cactus
content: I'll leave it to more mathy people to answer whether median or average is more appropriate.

author: foobar0x
content:
Thanks! Miner tip being <1% seems like the goal we want. 

I'm thinking of periods of sharp volatility, where immediate (arbitrage/liquidation bots) blockspace demand spikes, while basefee gets adjusted upwards slowly. Would miner tips dominate the basefee in the case where there's a profitable liquidation to be had, first come first served?

author: foobar0x
content: I suppose that basefee becomes exponentially increasing rather quickly, so this tip > basefee scenario wouldn't persist for more than 10 minutes at a time.

author: sky.cactus
content:
The inclusion fee is generally expected to be flat at around 1 nanoeth for all cases except:
1. Paying for position within a block
2. During times where the demand increases by over 2x in a short period.

author: foobar0x
content: Can you elaborate on #1? Do you mean "I want to be the first tx in this block, not the 50th"? Or enabling sandwich attacks?

author: foobar0x
content: Seems like it would require outside coordination for these, in which case the miner tip could also be paid via a sidechannel.

author: sky.cactus
content: I want to be first in the block.

author: foobar0x
content: Makes sense. If I send in a tx with a large tip, the miner receives the tip no matter if my transaction is at the start or end of the block. So how does the tipping mechanism affect within-block ordering without outside coordination and long-term trust?

author: ankur2534
content: the only reason a txsender would send with high tip is because they know the clients default to sorting high gasprice first. It's a nash equilibrium as miners would like to continue encouraging high gasprice txs for positional ordering

author: foobar0x
content: Oh, interesting. So it's a sort of consensus among miners to put the highest-paying transactions first, so that arbitrageurs continue to pay high amounts.

author: foobar0x
content: I found this simulation very helpful in understanding behavior during a jump impulse (demand increases >2x in a short period): https://barnabemonnot.com/abm1559/notebooks/stationary1559.html
